title: Monday, 17th June 2019
bodyHTML:
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Hey. Hello. Good morning.

Blank canvas Good morning all, welcome back BE
Soundbuy Morning

Back to 11.10am starts. Sorry about that. Sorry, also, for me.

Noname Good morning y'all
JP11:11am

Good morning BE.

Grouchmonkey Morning all

And howdy to ROTR.

BE11:12am

Hello, JP. Ta for keeping things ticking over last week in my absence.

Tony Scott morning all
nightingale20201 morning all

No problem. Friday was a bit of a struggle, but otherwise we had enough to discuss.

Kier have more kitchen sinks than Ed Miliband.

BE11:14am

Oh, and this thing.

11:13 am

BE11:14am

The Woodford Death Spiral Trust.

Founded by Ken Mulvany in late 2013, BenevolentAI aims to use its technology to combe vast troves of medical data — from clinical trials to academic papers — to help researchers “find new ways to treat and target diseases and to personalise drugs for the patients that benefit most from them.”

Soundbuy Aye..........BenevolentAI excellent read though i got a tad lost......
11:16 am
BE11:16am

And to summarise a deeply reported bit of work to one sentence, it's nothing? Yes? It's vapourware?

Soundbuy ..........actually very lost..........
JP11:17am

It makes big promises, with little to show for it.

JP11:17am

(@Soundbuy -- sorry, I tried to make it as clear as possible...almost killed me last week.)

fortyeight To be fair the fund in question has largely moved out of high street retail and avoided the worst of the problems.
Soundbuy @JP -no, it's me...............honestly.............
11:18 am
BE11:18am

A med-tech company that promises and draws in non-specialist investment without really delivering anything? Cripes.

BE11:18am

(@Ghazali: moderating that. Hope you can understand why.)

ronin Hehe, WPCT was the first stock I bought in UK (liked the premise) but dropped soon after for a small gain when I realised he had no technical knowhow with which to judge what he was dealing with.
Ghazali but the argument would be - isn't this exactly what valley VC firms do as well? and on occasion PE firms? i.e. buy a stake, revalue on a sale to their next fund etc....earn fees generate IRR and keep lobbing the company to the next fund
FjordFiesta I see that Airbus have - as predicted - twisted the knife with the 321XLR. Going to be a tough Paris for Boeing.
BE11:19am

Anyway. go read that as a companion to Kadhim's classic 2016 piece on Industrial Hokum.

11:19 am
JP11:19am

Thanks BE.

BE11:19am

And let's push on with today..

Pharma Personalised medicine is an excellent way of fragmenting potential drug markets so that they all become uneconomic.
undefined
11:19 am

................ So! Lufthansa.

BE11:20am

Down 11% live .....

BE11:20am

..... Profit warning. European short-haul to blame.

Happychachi Good thing that medicine isn't driven solely by economic factors ...
11:21 am

Price war, particularly in .... uh, Germany and Austria

Ghazali @ BE - yes. no worries. was also thinking about how best to state something that looks suspicious.
Ghazali clearly didn't do it well enough.

Where Lufthansa -- to state the obvious -- has a big share .....

Waterloo Liquid biopsy already changing the way cancer is treated making it very personalised

11:22 am

........... Adding capacity and undercutting itself.

BE11:22am

..... with an unprofitable airline. It's brilliant. Just brilliant.

That does not sound like an optimal business strategy.

11:22 am

Anyway, sector's down on the idea that this isn't just Lufthansa being terrible at airline-ing.

Blank canvas Anything of substance on Babcock, if you have time

.... though, frankly, it's mostly Lufthansa. Any sellside around?

Pharma @Waterloo, cancer may be the exception. Antibody treatments are generic enough that safety problems are minimised, while their specificity can be tailored to the individual.
JP11:24am

Here's UBS:

11:24 am
JP11:24am

Downward revision to guidance based on short haul environment
While long haul remains strong especially on transatlantic and Asian routes, the European short haul network (especially Germany and Austria) is under increased pressure due to over-capacity and need to defend home markets. The long haul yield strength is not sufficient to offset short haul weakness and the company has revised guidance for group margin to 5.5%-6.5% from 6.5%-8% which results in a material downgrade to guidance.

JP11:24am

Company now expects adjusted ebit of €2-2.4bn
Given the guidance change the company now forecasts adjusted ebit of €2-2.4bn. Consensus is currently €2.7bn (UBSe €2.9bn) so there is a material downgrade to consensus (c20% at midpoint to consensus). This factors in a smaller fuel headwind of €550m from the previous €700m so pricing weakness is weighing in as well as some cost pressures at Eurowings.

JP11:24am

Network airline margin revision materially smaller vs. Eurowings
LH now forecasts a small revision to network margins of 7-9% vs previous 7.5-9.5%. However, Eurowings which was previously forecast to see a flat margin is now forecast to see a margin of -4% to -6% given short haul pressures as well as slower progress on the cost reduction front. Nevertheless, the Network airline CC unit revenues for the full year 2019 are expected to be single digit down while Eurowings expected mid-single digit down. Currently we forecast flat CC yields for the group.

11:24 am
JP11:24am

Valuation: we value Lufthansa on 4.3x EV/EBITDA
Given weakness in cargo (especially Europe to Asia) cargo margins revised from 7-9% to 3-5%. Furthermore the company is making a €340m tax provision relating to 2001-5. Despite the shares seeing prior weakness and the coming CMD we think shares will see material weakness and likely drive the sector down. The CMD on 24th June will be the next time we hear from the company but the warning might overshadow the CMD. We value Lufthansa on 4.3x EV/Ebitda and rate Buy.

Grouchmonkey Speaking of airlines - is there anything happening at Norwegian? Seem to have been some rather odd delays according to the anecdotal evidence.
JP11:25am

It's kind of funny though, because there's also UBS note out on EU airlines this AM that's quite positive:

ronin @Pharma: isn't there a problem if drug markets can only profitable if the agent in question is applied to patients where it offers nothing?
JP11:25am

Initial indications are for a stronger October yield environment than SeptemberIn our view given the revenue weight of near term bookings on airline revenues both third party fare providers and airline comments on fare visibility should be viewed more as anecdotal. However, on the whole October pricing trends are stronger than September.Network pricing on the whole still appears better than low cost over summer;On the whole per the RDC Apex platform easyJet and Ryanair are showing greater deterioration in the pricing outlook than networks. However, Wizz summer pricing trends continue to be strong.

11:25 am
JP11:25am

Besides Eurowings Lufthansa pricing continues to reassureWhile Eurowings pricing indications remain weak on the whole the rest of the Lufthansa brands appear to show reassuring yield development over summer. The company has a CMD on 24th June so we expect a trading update from them on summer trends.Start to Air France pricing trends over summer appear weakEarly indications (based on six month prior to departure data) of Air France summer pricing appears weaker than British Airways and Lufthansa. Nevertheless, the data reflects a low percentage of bookings and it is the near term bookings which will determine the yields over summer.

hornblower is this going to make it harder for Lufthansa to buy the Thomas Cook airline?
BE11:26am

(@Pharma: I may be misunderstanding, but my impression was that all efforts to move immuno-oncology out of very narrow indications remain disappointing and the concepts have largely been abandoned at the primary end of the pipe.)

Waterloo @pharma, indeed although liquid biopsy will be able to tell if a drug will/can work. With cancer drugs often very expensive, knowing if it will work before dosing is a game changer, including for pharma IMO
BE11:26am

Hm ..... this note from Citi caught my eye.

Soundbuy Easyjet briefly touched £18 last June...........jeez
11:27 am
BE11:27am

The weakness in short-haul has been broadly expected, in our view, by the market for many weeks now. Many investors [as per our numerous feedback notes] believed that the guidance would be moved to the lower end of the previous guidance range [i.e. EUR2.4bn]…so the magnitude [with the lower end now at EUR2.0bn] may surprise a few on the downside.

BE11:27am

That said, with a capital markets day next Monday, we have been seeing [via our conversations] a wall of willing & complicit hedge fund money in recent weeks keen to buy the shares [and they were only holding off in light of this imminent downgrade]. Therefore while the shares may be weak at the open, we expect them to see buoyancy on the upside through the day.

BE11:28am

Which ...... hasn't happened yet. But is there an angle to the "wall of willing & complicit hedge fund money" thing?

11:28 am
JP11:28am

How to catch a falling knife.

BE11:29am

Because there's a not unreasonable chance that Luft shareholders will be on the hook for funding a consolidation.

JP11:29am

How will that work? Issue more equity?

11:30 am
BE11:30am

It's not impossible .... which doesn't seem typical HF territory. And I guess there's a cost story, which surely involves selling Eurowings not doubling its size by buying Thomas Cook Air or whatever.

Pharma @ronin, while on an individual level that might seem bad, it probably represents the greatest good for the greatest number. Developing multiple drugs to treat sub-populations better does not benefit from economies of scale. Further, if the lack of effect is the result of metabolic differences, it may prove impossible to develop alternative treatments.
Thomas Cook Group plc (TCG:LSE): Last: 15.05, down 0.1 (-0.66%), High: 15.50, Low: 14.70, Volume: 2.81m
BE11:31am

If Lufthansa is increasingly an event play, what chances of that deal ever completing?

11:31 am
JP11:31am

Here's Morgan Stanley to round things off:

BE11:31am

Thumbs up

JP11:31am

We expect Lufthansa shares to be significantly down on the back of new EBIT
guidance for 2019, which sits 18% below consensus. We believe ongoing pressure
in shorthaul pricing in the summer may also read across to the peer group, in
particular the LCCs exposed to these markets.
Lufthansa reduced EBIT margin guidance for 2019 to 5.5-6.5% which will drive
EBIT of €2-2.4bn,a 13% decline versus prior guidance of margin of 6.5-8% on up
to mid single digit revenues. The mid range EBIT of €2.2bn sits 18% below BBG
consensus of €2.7bn and 22% below 2018. The implied revenue target is for a
growth of 1-3% yoy,also below prior targets.

11:31 am
JP11:31am

The downgrade is attributed to tougher competition in Europe, which is driving
down prices and load factors. The EBIT guidance for networks has been reduced
to 7-9% margin (7.5-9.5%) and Eurowings guidance has moved from breakeven to
a 4-6% negative margin. Germany and Austria are cited as the key markets where
competition is intensifying. The Cargo business has also been underperforming
versus company expectations and itnow sees flat revenues yoy and margins of
3-5% (vs 7-9% prior target).

JP11:32am

We obtain our €24.00 pricetarget from a EV / EBITDA multiples-based approach. We
use our forecast FY20e EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxation, depreciation,
amortisation). We calculate 12-month forward bull and bear EBITDA scenarios based on
flex of passenger yield and EBITDA margin assumptions. We apply an EV multiple to
EBITDA in line with the historical median (4.0x) to each case and calculate the average
implied EV. We calculate an adjusted net debt metric for each scenario: starting with
balance sheetnet debt, which now includes the lease debt on balance sheet and
Lufthansa's pension deficit. Subtraction of the average of the adjusted net debt
scenarios from the average EV provides an implied equity value, which we discount at
the cost of equity (8.8%) to provide a 12-month forward implied equity value.
Thekeyrisk is that the many pillars ofLufthansa's multi-brand growth strategyin
aggregate producea netearnings profile different than ourexpectation. Beyond this,
Lufthansa is exposed to industry risks including currency movements (Lufthansa
operates in 80+ currencies), demand changes,and supplier cost changes including jet
fuel price,and in recognition maintains a hedging programme.Lufthansa's exposure to
aviation related segments including catering and maintenance expose it to additional and
different risks from other airlines (e.g. regulatory risk, different customer bases) but the
presence of these segments likely mitigates some risk from the aviation segment given
the exposure of these businesses to different parts of the economic cycle.

BE11:32am

That's comprehensive. Ta.

11:32 am
JP11:32am

Wink smile

"on 23 January 2019 it
received an unsolicited and highly preliminary proposal from Serco regarding a potential all-share combination between the two companies confirms that no further proposal has been received

11:37 am
JP11:37am

Apparently the board:

JP11:37am

...carefully considered the proposal and unanimously rejected it, having concluded that a combination of the two companies had no strategic merit and was not in the best interests of Babcock’s shareholders, customers or wider stakeholders/

BE11:38am

Okay. So Rupert Soames -- the Serco CEO and former Annabel's DJ -- is quite well respected for whatever reason.

red @Pharmaits just optics, shareholders still own the lot
11:37 am
JP11:38am

He's funny.

BE11:38am

Whereas Babcock's team, not wishing to be impolite, would
have shareholders queuing up to pay their taxi fares to the airport.

Pharma @red aren't bad bank structures usually a preamble to dumping stuff quietly onto the state?
BE11:39am

Now ... I don't know how this nil-premium story appeared in the press .... but ...... well, let's cut to Jefferies.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

1) The UK government has a golden share of Babcock’s Devonport and Rosyth subsidiaries so the pool of potential suitors is limited; 2) Babcock recently changed Chair, rebased profit guidance, and used its CMD to communicate medium-term growth potential so the Board is committed to recovery rather than a short-term transaction - “a combination of the two companies had no strategic merit and was not in the best interests of Babcock's shareholders, customers or wider stakeholders.”; 3) A merger would lock Babcock shareholders into relative underperformance versus Serco; 4) Serco’s recent NSBU acquisition was applauded as it diluted UK exposure.

Patience @BE - real rationale for the Serco bid surely to reduce competition as a way of increasing future profitability of outsourcer providers :-(
BE11:40am

[We] can see some merit in a merger – Babcock, in our view, needs a new management team to restore credibility, there would be decent synergies
given the overlap and Serco’s platform can take more revenue, although it would increase its exposure to the UK.
However, given the impending change in Chairman at Babcock and the fact that Serco has just done a US deal and raised money – the timing may now have
passed, although the fact that all this has been leaked now, may suggest that interested parties wanted to bring the approach to Babcock’s beleaguered
shareholders' attention.
Fundamental view
We continue to be positive on Serco, believing it has reached an inflection point in growth, margins and FCF and that the risk of disappointment is now low given
good visibility and a high rebid win rate.
We remain at SP on Babcock, but do see valuation upside if management changes are made to improve credibility and instil more confidence in the numbers.
We suspect BAB shareholders will be disappointed not to have had any input in the decision to rebuff SRP

red no state support allowed according to eu law which is the only game changer tho i expect once it becomes a critical mkt issue they will allow it
Noname Anyone tune in to the debate/anyone think it actually matters what is said on these debates?
JP11:41am

And here's Panmure:

A. M. @Patience: meta scope-creep?
11:41 am
JP11:41am

Babcock’s statementwas in response to weekend media speculation. The Sunday Times carried the story that Serco made a preliminary approach to Babcock at the end of last year, which was rejected, and then Serco returned with a more detailed proposal on 23January. Babcock has a market cap of £2.3bn and Serco of £1.7bn so we note that it would be case of the smaller business taking over the larger one. Whilst Babcock’s statementsays that the proposal has “no strategic merit” we can see logic for the combination. In particular there is some overlap between the two businesses in terms of their exposure to Defence, the UK and the public sector. Defence is 53% of Babcock’s revenue and 29% of Serco’s, the UK is 70% of Babcock’s revenues and 50% of Serco’s and the public sector is 80% of Babcock’s revenue and around 90% of Serco’s. Also, Serco is a more international company than Babcock and one of Babcock’s main goals is to increase the proportion of non-UK revenues, which a combination with Serco would help. Serco’s shares have also outperformed Babcock’s in recent years and trade on a much high rating (PER for Serco of 17.8x in Dec-20 on Reuter’s estimates and for Babcock of 6.2x in March-21), suggesting that the market may have more confidence in the outlook for Serco

JP11:42am

Against the logic of the merger, we think Babcock’s low relative valuation will have discouraged management from wanting to crystalise value at these levels. Plus, the main overlap between the two businesses is in UK defence and the UK’s Ministry of Defence may not want a further round of supplier consolidation having previously allowedBabcock to buy VT in 2010. Since 23 January, Serco’s shares have risen by 23% and Babcock’s have declined by 14% and we have cut our estimates for Babcock three times, which could make Serco more interested. However, in May Serco bought a US defence business (Alion’s Naval System Business Unit) for £173m, mainly financed by a £130m equity raise, which may suggest that having been rebuffed by Babcock it has turned its acquisition strategy elsewhere. Babcock also appointed a new Chairperson, Ruth Cairnie, in April and she may want more time to consider the strategic outlook for Babcock, especially with the company having set out its medium term strategy at this month’s capital markets day, before considering any new bid approaches

Pharma @red, this is a German bank, so ultimately EU rules will be bent if required.
BE11:42am

(@Patience: my impression was that the world doesn't lack heavy industry public service outsourcers. Most, however, seem to be the foreign commercial arms of state or quasi state-owned companies.)

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Divi's gone.

red mkt cap to debt ratio getting critical
BE11:47am

There's a firesale but no real guidance in terms of when debt will be under control.

BE11:47am

Here's Numis on the latter theme.

chad_john Anything on The Works? Big drop today apropos of not a lot from a glance.
Soundbuy Nice pic.............been to parties like that........
11:47 am
BE11:48am

The company does not outline any expectations on debt reduction other than "a significant reduction...during the coming year", but clearly investors will want some assurance that disposals and actions can materially reduce debt. On NSe, axing the dividend will save £62m in FY 2020, and on TNAV of £120m in the residential business (ex £60m strategic land not included in sale) we believe sales proceeds of £100m/0.8x P/NAV is achievable. Reducing investment in Property should enable cash inflows of c.£100m according to management (pre potential sale of the remaining £84m of capital employed). In aggregate, we believe Kier should have the ability to reduce debt by c.£260m through stated actions pre-retained earnings benefits plus EV benefits of average WC movements in these areas. We note that management is now aiming for £55m of annual cost savings through FPK by 2021, but diminished industry confidence in Kier could also impact earnings potential unless arrested in the near future. The timescale for material net debt reduction has to be 12 months maximum in our view.

BE11:48am

"material value exists in the business and saleable assets can provide the solution to Kier's debt profile, but issues need to be bottomed out for value to be realised," Numis adds.

red also small matter of 56m in costs of nxt 2 years to achieve that 55m from 2021. u are betting they are still around come 2021
JP11:49am

And here's Peel Hunt, who has placed the stock under "review". Price target was 900p...

11:49 am
JP11:49am

(@red -- the famous market cap to debt ratio. Brought to you by Netflix.)

JP11:49am

Strategic review – The Board has concluded that debt levels are too high and there has been insufficient focus on cash generation during a period of acquisition-led growth. Under the new CEO Andrew Davies, Kier will: (1) focus on Regional Building, Infrastructure, Utilities and Highways (c70% FY18 EBITA); (2) sell (or substantially exit) non-core activities, including Kier Living (Residential) and Property; and (3) continue to restructure the group – targeting cost savings of at least £55m (from FY21). We welcome these steps.

JP11:49am

Asset value realisation – Kier Living has a tangible net asset value of £120m (excluding land (£60m) that Kier is likely to retain but impair). A sale would also have working capital, supply chain finance and non-recourse JV debt benefits (PHe c£180m). Within Property, management expects to reduce capital employed to c£100m in FY20 (vs H1 CE of £184m). We would expect proceeds ahead of this implied reduction. A full disposal is also considered possible.

11:49 am
JP11:49am

Debt update – Management expects FY19 average net debt to be £420-450m vs our previous £360m estimate. We understand that the key influences on this increased guidance is period-end movements in May, volatility in working capital due to counterparty concerns (£97m outflow in H1 that had been expected to reverse) and Kier accelerating payments to support the supply chain during this uncertainty. Kier has committed facilities of £920m (substantially to June 2022) and, using FY19 consensus EBITDA of £160m, the implied FY19 spot net debt (mid point £200m) remains well within covenants (3x ND/EBITDA). We are mindful that there are numerous potential scenarios and possibilities ahead. We place estimates under review until there is some further clarity on the period end position.

BE11:50am

(I think my favourite market cap to debt ratio is Liberty Global.)

BE11:50am

And Stifel .....

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Whilst it
is positive than management is taking decisive action, average month-end net debt of £420-450m
is higher than expected (Stifel c.£380m) with recent commentary having a negative effect on
confidence and working capital. This balance sheet weakness could impact the group's ability to get
appropriate value from its disposals.

BE11:50am

Well, yeah.

BE11:51am

Fire sales are fire sales.

Snowman @BE or Eurotunnel
red i mean in regards to shrinking mkt cap to debt to be precise.once u get to point that a rights is no longer viable, things often snowball to a bitter end.
Shinshin Going to switch my portfolio to illiquid alts this week. Do we expect any Mifid-compliant notes from Shrewdette ?
chopper bear anyone wish to help my IAG or EZJ Quandary ?
11:51 am
BE11:52am

(@Snowman: Eurotunnel's a good one, though it's an infrastructure sort of business. What does Liberty own apart from a mouthy CEO?)

hornblower @red - I agree, once mkt cap below debt things tend to go badly
BE11:52am

And Liberum .....

BE11:52am

A P/E of 2.2x is clearly discounting a lot of bad news. However, there is much to be concerned about. While expected net debt of £200m seems manageable the total creditor stack is too large. Disposals can reduce debt and probably more importantly reduce leverage ratios. However, events are moving fast and disposals are likely to be complicated, given the JVs in Property and Residential, they will be very dilutive (Property and Residential are c. 40% of pre-cost EBIT). We believe 2020 consensus may also be too high.

red its imperative to boost confidence or they will be done. got to stop that share price falling or vultures wont pay up. i wouldnt.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Pfizer to Acquire Array BioPharma
—Proposed acquisition strengthens Pfizer’s innovative biopharmaceutical business and is expected to accelerate its growth trajectory particularly in the long term

—Opportunity to strengthen category leadership in Oncology with the addition of a breakthrough combination of BRAF/MEK inhibitors under investigation for a potential first-in-class therapy for patients with BRAF-mutant metastatic colorectal cancer

—Expands Pfizer’s pipeline with multiple high-potential targeted investigational cancer therapies and adds a large portfolio of royalty-generating out-licensed medicines

—Plans to maintain highly productive research unit in Boulder to complement Pfizer’s research hubs

—Transaction valued at $48 per Array share in cash, for a total enterprise value of approximately $11.4 billion

ronin @Pharma: I'm not sure whether we are on the same page here. To use an actual example where we effectively practice personalised medicine, Herceptin is only used in breast cancer where there is proven HER2 amplification where it offers a marked improvement in survival. In other circumstances, it offers nothing. Would it be better if we deliberately ignored HER2 status and treated all breast cancers with Herceptin? Both treatment morbidity and unnecessary expense would surely rule out such an approach. The other issue I see there is already a pool of failed candidates that have passed toxicity trials, appear to have a sound, rational biological basis but failed to show efficacy at Phase 3. One wonders whether some of these could be effective in subpopulations and sample size effects prevent detection of this in the general Phase 3 trials. There's certainly enough failed alpha-beta 42 targeted candidates lying around and sufficient reason to believe that alpha-beta 42 aggregation should be a factor in Alzheimer's to investigate further. You've got the earlier phases paid for as a sunk cost already. If what you meant was that disease stratification has got to the stage that it is not economic to specifically develop de novo for some subpopulations, that may well be true. But I think most personalised medicine will proceed more along the lines of restricting the use of current general treatments only to those who will benefit from them and/or tailoring treatment timecourse accordingly.
